procedure: Left Total Hip Replacement for intracapsular displaced femoral neck fracture

extracted_info.summary: 87-year-old male with history of HTN, HLD, GERD, CAD s/p stents in 2015, and history of left SAH who presented after a mechanical fall with left hip pain and inability to ambulate. Imaging showed a left displaced femoral neck fracture. Patient is scheduled for left total hip replacement due to his high activity level and pre-fall unassisted ambulation.
diagnosis: History of stroke (atraumatic R cortical SAH)
key_information: Patient is active at baseline, walking 5000 steps per day and ambulating unassisted
History of coronary stent placement in 2015 (2 stents)
History of bilateral knee replacement
History of laparoscopic cholecystectomy
Patient is at high risk due to age and fracture type - provider notes 'femur fractures in the elderly are of the highest severity'
Non-weight bearing on left lower extremity ordered
DVT prophylaxis with HSQ pre-op, currently on hold
Medicine consult requested for pre-operative risk stratification
Spinal anesthesia preferred due to geriatric status

procedure: Left Total Hip Replacement for intracapsular displaced femoral neck fracture
extracted_info.summary: 87-year-old male who presented to the emergency room after a fall and was found to have a left hip displaced femoral neck fracture. The patient underwent a left total hip replacement with Smith & Nephew components including a 56mm Redapt Modular Shell, Size 5 Polarstem cemented hip stem, and 40mm +4 femoral head. The procedure was performed through an anterior approach with an estimated blood loss of 150cc, and the patient was made weight-bearing as tolerated postoperatively.

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.description: Total hip arthroplasty (THA), also referred to as total hip replacement (THR), involves removal of the femoral head and acetabulum and placement of a prosthesis anchored to the bone. The goal of the procedure is long-term pain relief and restoration of function. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L746-L749)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses hip arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 22, L756-L757)

documentation: Primary and secondary tumors of the proximal femur (Evidence: pg no: 24, L837)
Hip fracture or complications including malunion, nonunion or failed prior fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L838)
Failed previous hip fracture fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L839)
Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) with unresponsive severe pain (Evidence: pg no: 24, L840)
Revision of hip arthrodesis (Evidence: pg no: 24, L841)
Imaging evidence of significant joint destruction and cartilage loss, defined as Tönnis grade 3, modified Outerbridge grade III – IV, or Kellgren-Lawrence grade 3 – 4 (Evidence: pg no: 24, L844-L845)
Limited range of motion, antalgic gait and disabling pain of at least 3 months' duration (Evidence: pg no: 24, L846)
Pain with passive motion of the hip (Evidence: pg no: 24, L847)
Failure of at least 3 months of non-surgical conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 24, L848-L849)
Functional limitation secondary to hip pathology which interferes with the ability to perform age-appropriate daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 24, L850-L851)

exclusions: Indications for total hip arthroplasty other than those addressed in this guideline are considered not medically necessary (Evidence: pg no: 26, L937-L938)

codes.description: Arthroplasty, acetabular and proximal femoral prosthetic replacement (total hip arthroplasty), with or without autograft or allograft (Evidence: pg no: 27, L973-L974)

full_source.notes: All arthroplasty and acetabuloplasty/resection arthroplasty procedures are inclusive of synovectomy, removal of osteophytes, removal of loose bodies, manipulation of the hip, and release or repair of structures to gain entrance to the hip joint. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L749-L751)

full_source.description: Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty is similar to standard arthroplasty in that both components of the joint are replaced but the ball and socket portions of the joint are reversed, allowing the deltoid muscle to assume partial function of the rotator cuff. full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)

Impression and plan:

Renke B Thye is a 87 y.o. male sustained a Left displaced femoral neck fracture. Femur fractures in the elderly are of
the highest severity due to the morbidity without treatment and risk of death due to bed-ridden disability, risk of
ulcers, and risk of clot and other medical complications causing death. Therefore | had a long discussion with the
patient and their family about the treatment options, including nonoperative and operative intervention. We
discussed risks and benefits and alternatives to surgery as well as chances of full or partial weight bearing after.
After going over these options, we decided to pursue a left total hip replacement due to his activity level and pre-fall
high level unassisted ambulation.

We discussed the risks of surgery including infection, wound complications, bleeding, need for a transfusion, possible
damage to surronding neurovascular structures, potential for continued pain, continued weakness, worsening pain
and worsening weakness, stiffness, instability/dislocation, limb length discrepancy, fracture, infection requiring the
resection or revision arthroplasty, component loosening and the need for revision surgery in the future. We also
discussed the risks of thromboembolic complications, stroke, heart attack, cardiac event, heart failure, pulmonary
edema, fat/cement embolus, aspiration, death, and the risks of anesthesia and nerve blocks.

Would favor spinal anesthesia and early care as delay in care results in perioperative morbidity and mortality with
geriatric femur fractures.

- NPO/IVEF for OR this afternoon

- NWB LLE

- Pain control

- DVT: HSQ pre-op, on hold now

- appreciate Medicine consult for pre operative risk stratification
- Booked/consented/marked

Findings: Displaced subcapital left femoral neck fracture

Indication:

The patient is a 87 y.o. male who presented to our emergency room after a fall and was found to have a left hip
displaced femoral neck fracture. Femur fractures in the elderly are of the highest severity due to the morbidity without
treatment and risk of death due to bed-ridden disability, risk of ulcers, and risk of clot and other medical complications
causing death. Therefore | had a long discussion with the patient and their family about the treatment options,
including nonoperative and operative intervention. We discussed risks and benefits and alternatives to surgery as
well as chances of full or partial weight bearing after. We discussed the risks of surgery including infection, wound
complications, bleeding, need for a transfusion, possible damage to surronding neurovascular structures, potential for
continued pain, continued weakness, worsening pain and worsening weakness, stiffness, instability/dislocation, limb
length discrepancy, fracture, infection requiring the resection or revision arthroplasty, component loosening and the
need for revision surgery in the future. We also discussed the risks of thromboembolic complications, stroke, heart
attack, cardiac event, heart failure, pulmonary edema, fat embolus, aspiration, death, and the risks of anesthesia.
The potential benefits of surgery are pain relief or improvement, improved mobility, and allowance of immediate
weight bearing post-operatively. We also discussed some of the risks specific to the anterior approach including
numbness over the lateral thigh, wound complications, and femoral component loosening or fracture of the femur.
These risks were discussed in the context of other approaches, specifically the posterior approach and its associated
risks. The patient expressed an understanding of these risks and the patient wished to proceed with a total hip
replacement. We did discuss hemiarthroplasty, however given the patients high functional demand he and his wife
elected to proceed with a total hip replacement.

We also discussed the overall poor prognosis for patients who have suffered a femur fracture, with high morbidity and
mortality rates following this particular pattern of injury. The patient and family expressed understanding and elected
to proceed with a total hip replacement.

The patient was seen by the Medicine service and was determined to be optimized from a medical standpoint for this
surgery. The medicine team cleared the patient for surgery as well.

Description of procedure:
The patient was seen in the preoperative holding area and the appropriate side lower extremity was marked. Again a
discussion of the procedure was held with the patient and the patient wished to proceed.

The patient was brought to the Operating Room and a preliminary anesthesia time out was then performed. Spinal
anesthesia was then performed by the anesthesia team, however was unsuccessful and he was converted to
general. The patient was then placed supine on the operating room table. Preoperative antibiotics were administered
within thirty minutes of incision time as well as 1 gram of tranexamic acid. The patient was placed onto a sacral bump
on the operating room table. At this point, the patient's surgical area was prepped and draped in the standard, sterile
fashion. A surgical timeout was then performed to confirm the correct side, procedure, and name.

A longitudinal incision was made starting lateral and distal to the anterior superior iliac spine. The incision was
carried down through the subcutaneous tissues down to the level of the tensor fascia lata. The tensor fascia lata was
then divided sharply with care not to violate the muscle below. Blunt dissection of the fascia was done to identify the
interval between the tensor fascia lata and the sartorius. Once this was done and deeper retractors had been placed,
the ascending branch of the lateral femoral circumflex artery was clearly visualized and this was cauterized. Next, the
fat within this interval was dissected to better visualize the anterior hip capsule and the lateral border of the
iliocapsularis. At this point, a Cobb was used to elevate the iliocapsularis and rectus off the anterior capsule and a
retractor was placed underneath these muscles. At this point, a capsulectomy was performed along the axis of the
femoral neck and the intertrochanteric ridge. A large hemarthrosis from the fracture was encountered. The retractors
were now placed intracapsular and the head-neck junction was exposed. A release of the pubofemoral ligament was
then performed until the lesser trochanter could be palpated. Using the pre-operative templating, the appropriate
clean up neck cut was made and the femoral head and remaining neck was extracted.

The acetabulum was now visualized with the placement of retractors. At this point, the labrum and the contents of the
Thye, Renke B (MRN MR364652) Printed by Stagno, Cesarina [767] at 12/30/2025 4:21 PM 2/4

12/30/25, 4:22 PM Thye, Renke B (MR # MR364652) DOB: 07/30/1938

cotyloid fossa were removed. The acetabulum was then reamed sequentially, based on preoperative templating.
Reaming was performed carefully. Next, the final size 56mm acetabular component was impacted into the
appropriate position. The periphery of the acetabular component was inspected and any osteophytes were removed.
Once this was accomplished, the final 40mm neutral polyethylene liner was impacted into place. Care was taken to
ensure that the liner was fully seated and had engaged the locking mechanism.

Next, the acetabular retractors were removed and attention was turned to the femur. The leg was positioned in an
adducted and extended position. Retractors were then placed around the proximal femur to expose the cut neck
surface. Tight capsular tissue over the superior/anterior aspect of the femoral neck was released using cautery only
to allow for sufficient exposure. A curved double footed retractor was placed over the greater trochanter laterally and
a femoral retractor placed at the infero medial neck. Sequential releases were performed in order to allow for
accepted elevation of the femur, this was done in conjunction with gentle elevation with a bone hook.

The canal finder was then used to establish the IM canal. A box cutter was used to remove posterolateral bone of the
cut neck. Arasp and curette were used to remove lateral femoral neck bone remaining. An entry broach was
utilized, followed by sequential broaching up to the final size. With the broach left in place and after calcar planning,
the neck and trials were placed. The hip was reduced and found to be stable. Leg length, offset and implant size and
position were assessed clinically. Afterwards, the hip was dislocated. The trial components were removed.

The femoral canal was irrigated and a cement restrictor was placed down the canal. The canal was again rinsed and
dried. Cement was then placed in the canal and pressurized, and the final size 5 standard stem was placed in the
canal. After the cement hardened the actual 40mm +4 head was now impacted into place after cleaning and drying.
The hip was reduced with traction and internal rotation after confirming that the acetabular component was free of
any debris and had been irrigated.

The wound was then copiously irrigated and washed with a dilute betadine solution then with normal saline. Copious
irrigation was used throughout the closure. 1 gram of Vancomycin powder was placed in the deep wound. The fascia
overlying the TFL was now closed using running barbed suture, with care to not entrap any of the lateral femoral
cutaneous nerve branches. The remainder of the wound was closed in layers using #1 Vicryl, 2-0 Vicryl, 3-0 Monocry|
with prineo/Dermabond for skin. Standard mepilex dressing was applied in the standard fashion and the patient was
transferred to the Recovery Room in stable condition. All sponge, needle counts were correct x 2.

SN redapt/cemented polarstem components were used in this procedure.

Postoperative Plan:

WBAT: wbat

PT/OT: OOB and ambulation

Pain control: Oxycodone 5mg as needed for moderate pain; Tylenol for mild pain
DVT ppx: asa 81 bid

Periop ancef, followed by 7 days of cefadroxil due to high risk fracture
Colace 100mg BID while taking oxycodone

Keep dressing clean and dry

Zofran PRN while taking oxycodone

Resume Home Medications

Medical comanagement by hospitalist service, appreciate recommendations
Dispo: pending PT/OT eval
